<s_map><s_node-0><s_text>Vascular System</s_text><s_node-1><s_text>Choroid: This nourishes the outer layers of the retina and prevents internal reflection.</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Internal Carotid Artery</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Ophthalmic Artery</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>Anterior Ciliary Artery</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Recurrent branches</s_text></s_node-5><sep/><s_text>Posterior Ciliary Artery</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>Short Posterior</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>This supplies the posterior Choroid.</s_text></s_node-6><sep/><s_text>Long Posterior</s_text><s_node-6><s_text>This Supplies the anterior region of the choroid.</s_text></s_node-6></s_node-5></s_node-4></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Uveal vessels</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>provides nutrition and allows gas exchange.</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Vorticose Veins</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>The Choroidal blood leaves the choroid and pierces the Sclera. The veins branch from the back surface of the eye and the ciliary body, the blood empties into the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins.</s_text></s_node-3></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Retina: This senses light and creates impulses that travel via the optic nerve to the brain.</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Internal Carotid Artery</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Ophthalmic Artery</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>Central Retinal Artery This supplies the Inner Laminae</s_text><s_node-5><s_text></s_text><s_node-6><s_text>Radial Peripapillary Capillaries (RPC)</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>These are situated at the nerve fibre layer and are associated with the major superotemporal and inferotemporal vessels.</s_text></s_node-7><sep/><s_text>Outer Capillaries</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>These are parallel to the RPC and are found in the ganglion cell layer.</s_text></s_node-7><sep/><s_text>Superior</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>Nasal</s_text><sep/><s_text>Temporal</s_text></s_node-7><sep/><s_text>Inferior</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>Nasal</s_text><sep/><s_text>Temporal</s_text></s_node-7><sep/><s_text>Inner Capillaries</s_text><s_node-7><s_text>These travel form the inner plexiform layer to the outer plexiform layer.</s_text></s_node-7></s_node-6></s_node-5></s_node-4></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Central retinal vein</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>supplies the inner laminae and drains blood from the capillaries of the retina into larger veins outside the eye. The vein exits via the Optic nerve and drains into the cavernous Sinus.</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Choroidal Capillaries</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>These supply: the Rods and Cones  Outer Laminae  Outer Nuclear Layer They are fenestrated therefore slight resistance to allow the passage of small molecules.</s_text><sep/><s_text>Choroidal blood leaves the eye by the vortex veins.</s_text></s_node-3></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Optic Nerve: carries impulses from the retina to the brain.</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Pial Plexus</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Supplying the Orbital Portion, intracanlicular portion and the intracranial portion.</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Posterior Ciliary artery</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Short Posterior</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>These pierce the sclera around the entrance of the optic nerve. This supplies the anterior optic nerve.</s_text><sep/><s_text>Circle of Zinn & Haller: An elliptic circle around the optic nerve formed by the medial and lateral short posterior ciliary arteries.</s_text><s_node-5><s_text>supplies the intraocular portion.</s_text><sep/><s_text>Recurrent Pial branches</s_text><sep/><s_text>Choroidal Branches</s_text></s_node-5></s_node-4><sep/><s_text>Long Posterior</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>These pierce the posterior part of the sclera, which then travel along either side of the eyeball towars the ciliary muscle.</s_text></s_node-4></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Choroidal arteries</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Supplies the anterior Optic nerve.</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Central Retinal Artery</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Supplies the axons on the Optic disc. This branches into four major vessels, each supplying one quadrant of the retina.</s_text><sep/><s_text>Supplies the retrobulbar part of the nerve. This area is also supplied by the pial vessels.</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Central retinal Vein</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>The venous drainage of the optic nerve. This passes through the anterior optic nerve and empties into the superior ophthalmic vein.</s_text></s_node-3></s_node-2></s_node-1></s_node-0></s_map>

<s_map><s_node-0><s_text>Mobilization Orthoses</s_text><s_node-1><s_text>Types</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Serial-Static Orthotic Provisioin</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Purpose: immobilize a joint</s_text><sep/><s_text>Positions a joint near its elastic limits to overcome a loss in passive ROM</s_text><sep/><s_text>Recommended for contractures w/ hard end feel</s_text><sep/><s_text>Recommended across the continuum of healing</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Dynamic Orthotic Provision</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Purpose: to apply sufficient tension that does not overpower the joint and allows the client to overcome the resistance and move in the opposite direction</s_text><sep/><s_text>Recommended when collagen is forming</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>Static-Progressive Orthotic Provision</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>Has inelastic components to apply torque to a joint in order to statically position the joint as close as possible to end range</s_text><sep/><s_text>Recommended during the proliferative and chronic stages of tissue healing when collagen is forming</s_text></s_node-3></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Biomechanical Principles</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Anatomical Considerations</s_text><sep/><s_text>Mechanical Advantage</s_text><sep/><s_text>Torque</s_text><sep/><s_text>Force</s_text></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Common Features</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Outrigger</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>A projection from the orthotic base</s_text><sep/><s_text>High</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>Results in less deviation bulky</s_text></s_node-4><sep/><s_text>Low</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>Requires adjustments more frequently but aeshetically pleasing</s_text></s_node-4></s_node-3></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Goals</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>Correction of deformities</s_text><sep/><s_text>Substitute for loss of muscle function</s_text><sep/><s_text>Provide Controlled Motion</s_text><sep/><s_text>Aid in wound healing</s_text></s_node-2></s_node-1></s_node-0></s_map>

<s_map><s_node-0><s_text>Permaculture and Ecosocial Design process</s_text><s_node-1><s_text>introduction</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>the framework of a project is design structure</s_text><sep/><s_text>the design process moves from patterns to details</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>aka: the design process contains methods</s_text><sep/><s_text>http://permacultureprinciples.com</s_text><sep/><s_text>"every situation there is a design opportunity</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>all social and human situations are realities created by us they are open to endless design and re-design</s_text><sep/><s_text>social reality isnt fixed</s_text><sep/><s_text>there is endless opportunity for ecosocial design practice</s_text></s_node-4></s_node-3></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>what kind of process to use?</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>analytical</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>design frameworks with sequenced phases including goals articulation, thorough data collection/analysis and careful problem definition are the core and are essential if design efforts are to be relevant and effective.</s_text><sep/><s_text>ex: engineers</s_text><sep/><s_text>pitfalls:</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>tendency to avoid thinking out side the box</s_text><sep/><s_text>dismiss appropriateness of automated solutions used</s_text><sep/><s_text>insist on following plans even if they become irrelevant/irrational to use</s_text></s_node-4></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>intuitive</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>encourage creativity and wholistic approach to design</s_text><sep/><s_text>seek to employ sensing processes in which we feel for energies in order to intuit what is seeking to emerge and then go with that</s_text><sep/><s_text>ex:artists</s_text><sep/><s_text>pitfalls:</s_text><s_node-4><s_text>unresolved emotional issues clouding the intuition</s_text><sep/><s_text>tendency to generate whimsical designs</s_text><sep/><s_text>conflate mystery with quality: "if i cant explain it it must be good"</s_text></s_node-4></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>both/and?</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>it would be optimal to take the best of both! (analytical/intuitive)</s_text></s_node-3></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>integrating analytical/intuitive</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>permaculture designers are an example of how this is done</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>they collect hunches inspirations and wild ideas in a folder and save them for later</s_text><sep/><s_text>the designer is free to create wild designs with no judgement at any time</s_text><sep/><s_text>but also willing to let go of them if they prove unfruitful</s_text><sep/><s_text>the use of intuitive methods like multiple sit spots and fully sensing a space, while making (analytical) concrete, hypothetical deductions from nature through thoughtful application of prior knowledge of plant and animal successions and behaviors</s_text></s_node-3></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>the value of templates ect...</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>templates/procedures/rituals aid us in learning a space that is unfamiliar and/ or complex</s_text><sep/><s_text>Bill Molison encourages students to take on peoples "too difficult box"</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>working through a templated process or framework gives us a place to start collecting data/know how to start, even if we dont know what the end result or plan will be.</s_text><sep/><s_text>goal articulation, and survey and analysis phases often allow the situation to reveal the underlying shapes and patterns in the context that can provide us with clues as to what to do next</s_text><sep/><s_text>"the pattern":When working on land-based designs collecting the following data (making a survey) is bound to be of essential and significant value. Therefore survey for : - 1) Slope, sectors and aspect, 2) Soils and water, 3) Microclimates, 4) Existing vegetation and 5) Current patterns of use in relation to zone and sector analysis.</s_text></s_node-3></s_node-2><sep/><s_text>Frameworks, cycles, and templates</s_text><s_node-2><s_text>The key is to be conscious of what you are doing, be able to articulate (and document) what went well, what was challenging, what you would do differently next time and to evaluate if your choices were good.</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>GADIE: by permaculture designer Dave Jacke</s_text><sep/><s_text>O'Brediment from the UK</s_text><sep/><s_text>SADI from UK school of landscaping</s_text><sep/><s_text>GoSADIMET- combines all of the above</s_text><sep/><s_text>Pattern Languages</s_text><sep/><s_text>Appreciative Inquiry</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>GADIE:</s_text><s_node-3><s_text>G: goals- articulate goals</s_text><sep/><s_text>A: analyze and assess</s_text><sep/><s_text>D: design</s_text><sep/><s_text>I: Implement</s_text><sep/><s_text>E: evaluate</s_text></s_node-3><sep/><s_text>stages are arranged in a spiral so the process never ends</s_text></s_node-2></s_node-1></s_node-0></s_map>
